fields.description: Useful to occasionally do it, and to be able to invoke that mode with a keyboard shortcut.  http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/178-shortcut-to-commit-all
fields.summary: Keyboard shortcut to commit -a even with staging view enabled

fields.description: xibs and xuserdatad are the main culprits.  http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/177-disabling-automatic-diff-ing
fields.summary: Disable diff for file patterns

fields.description: Someone with multiple monitors suggested being able to tear off the diff view to a different monitor?  Hmm.  http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/problems/349-evaluation
fields.summary: Tear-off windows

fields.description: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/174-avoid-using-red-highlighting-for-things-that-arent-problems  Bad stderr output.
fields.summary: Suppress red highlighting of non-errors?

fields.description: You can't do it right now (git revert needs the -m option) - should we allow?
fields.summary: Backout a merge in git

fields.description:
More git hosting services are popping up all the time, some of which have an API (e.g. Unfuddle, Codebasehq.com), and also many people self-host on gitweb, cgit and potentially others. We can probably never keep up with every service explicitly, so it would be nice to have a way for the user to plug in some kind of hook to support whatever API they wanted, so that their projects will appear on the Hosted Projects view (of course, any hosting service at all can still be used regardless just by using the clone/remote URL).

Probably don't want to make this a native plugin, because that's trickier for people to write and also might have security issues. Ideally some kind of scripting hook might be best. Don't want to add a whole scripting engine to SourceTree just for this, maybe we can repurpose AppleScript, Python or even just call out to a shell script of the user's choice.
fields.summary: Pluggable API options for Hosted Projects

fields.description: Be able to list pull requests from both systems, and pull into the branch of your choosing easily. Also close when commit?
fields.summary: Pull requests on GitHub / Bitbucket

fields.description: Some people prefer narrow views. Add the option to stack views vertically instead to make this possible. Shouldn't be too hard, just 2 top-level containers for each view.
fields.summary: Vertical screen arrangement option

fields.description: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/problems/319-renamed-a-directory-and-sourcetree-does-not-see-the-change
fields.summary: Support renaming folders

fields.description:
Several users have requested an option to always display the full output of git/hg commands, either because they like to learn from the commands issued, or just like to see the full results. 

There should be an option in the Preferences dialog to allow them to do this, instead of trying to 'catch' the disclosure triangle in the task window in time.
fields.summary: Allow user to ask for full output to always be shown (via prefs)

fields.description: While re-vamping the Bookmarks view, add a search box.  http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/156-want-a-view-filter-menu-for-bookmarks-window
fields.summary: Bookmarks enhancement - search

fields.description: Ability to bring up the bookmarks and switch directly.  Maybe fake this by opening a new window with the same dimensions, active view settings and splitter positions then closing the other one. This would avoid having to hugely re-engineer the separate hg and git repo windows.
fields.summary: Allow switching between repositories in same window

fields.description: A bit like reversing an entire commit, but you can do it on just part of a diff.
fields.summary: Reverse selected hunk/lines/file in working copy

fields.description: Rebase has it's problems but it's useful for simplifying. Also fetch extension is great but has some issues.   If the goal is to make things simpler for most people when they update from upstream, maybe some kind of streamlined 'Pull and Merge' assistant would be useful. If there were no outstanding changes, pull & merge (and check for conflicts), if there are outstanding changes maybe stash, pull, merge & apply stash (or use MQ)
fields.summary: Pull & Merge assistant

fields.description: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/questions/59-some-way-to-export-files-from-a-revision
fields.summary: 'Export File' option on Log Selected / History
Support Quick Look in Log Selected window too

fields.description: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/134-multiple-file-select-ignore
fields.summary: Allow multiple file selection for ignore

fields.description: It's the proper way to do things on OS X anyway. Requested here: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/128-persistent-folder-reference-in-the-bookmark-window  Carbon API reference: http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/Carbon/Reference/Alias_Manager/Reference/reference.html Obj-C wrapper: https://github.com/nathanday/ndalias
fields.summary: Use aliases for local repos so moves etc are tracked

fields.description:
Right now in Git we're pushing all tags (behaves like Mercurial). Really we need to give people the option not to push all tags, and to push a selection of tags instead. 

In addition, you should be able to push tags individually from the sidebar, just like branches.
fields.summary: Git push tags - don't push all tags option, select tags

fields.description: Most useful at git staging time, but can be edited any time. http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/122-staging-with-comments
fields.summary: Allow commit comment to be edited any time before commit

fields.description: Instead of just the incoming / outgoing output, a full log view that you can browse. TortoiseHg has this allegedly.  Requested a couple of times, including by aras_p
fields.summary: Incoming/outgoing - full diff

fields.description: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/105-send-email-option-on-changeset  'There are times when I need to send an email to the person who committed a changeset. It would be really helpful if there was an option in SourceTree that would invoke the default mail program to send a new message to that person, populating the subject line with something related to the changeset and repo. Ideally I could configure that to be either plain text or HTML as well (I happen to use Outlook 2011).'
fields.summary: Send email from log / search

fields.description: Very useful for team environments.   http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/88-use-committemplate-config-setting
fields.summary: Commit template option

fields.description: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/97-blame-view-improvements  Colour-code by author Include date/time of change
fields.summary: Blame view enhancements

fields.description: 'hg push -r' is hugely useful if you want to keep multiple unresolved heads on a branch but still push one (the assumption is that you'll merge later).  You can do this in the push dialog under advanced, but it would be really useful to be able to right-click the log and do it.
fields.summary: Simplify 'hg push -r' with log right-click

fields.description: If a tag is remote then you must be able to remove it, Removed in the same way as remote branches.  Probably want to default to removing
fields.summary: Remove remote tag in Git

fields.description: What do you know, someone does want this after all: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/64-ignores-view-toggling-and-batch-operations  Basically push / pull all outstanding so you can get up to speed / sync easily.
fields.summary: Pull / Push All

fields.description: Although you can select a file and choose to ignore its parent, this is not as intuitive as selecting the folder. This is only possible in the tree and browser views of course.  As requested here: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/64-ignores-view-toggling-and-batch-operations
fields.summary: Ignore folders more obviously in tree/browser views

fields.description: As requested here: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/48-cli-tools  User would like a command-line tool which opened the current repo in SourceTree. Also optionally create a Bookmark.
fields.summary: Command-line utility

fields.description: Would be nice to have an option to notify via Mountain Lion notifications and/or Growl when the number of pullable changes increases.
fields.summary: Mountain Lion / Growl notification of new pullable items?

fields.description: As suggested here: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/47-dock-options  Would be good to be able to right-click and select bookmarks.
fields.summary: Add custom Dock menu options

fields.description: If the user chooses to specify the folder that way.
fields.summary: Drag & drop to destination folder should replace not append

fields.description: Right now the Quick Look view just fades in. It would be nice if it zoomed out of the origin point. I think this is a delegate method which I'm not implementing yet.  Not essential but would be nice.
fields.summary: Quick Look extension: supply origin rectangle for zoom

fields.description: With the single pane view combined with not showing lines in between, it's hard to see the context of conflicts. It's also impossible to see multiline changes.
fields.summary: Add Side-by-side view in diff panel

fields.description: Would be useful to be able to generate HTML / XML Changelog between 2 versions or since a given tag. Think of what I do whenever I do a release!
fields.summary: Generate Changelog

fields.description: Because the 'push' option on commit only pushes existing tracked branches, any commits on new branches actually push nothing.  It also pushes commits you've made previously on tracked branches. This should probably be clearer.  Maybe have a 'details' rollout which looks basically the same as the push dialog.
fields.summary: Pushing a new branch on commit silently does nothing

fields.description: Octopus merges are currently not supported, both in the merge dialog and in the log display (a single second parent is supported only)
fields.summary: Git octopus merges

fields.description: Mercurial & Git, support repositories with no working copy
fields.summary: Support for bare repositories

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When HTML encoding is used for URL's host name then DefaultRedirectPolicy should recognize it.

For example {{//example.co%26%23x6d%3b}} is {{//examplem}} is {{//example.com}}
h3. Steps to Reproduce
  Change test {{com.atlassian.seraph.config.TestDefaultRedirectPolicy#testAllowAnyFalse}} and append following line
 {{assertTrue(redirectPolicy.allowedRedirectDestination("//example.com/jira",}} mockJirarequest));

h3. Expected Results

Test passes
h3. Actual Results

Test fails
h3. Workaround


 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: DefaultRedirectPolicy doesn't recognize URL with HTML-encoding

projectCategory.description: Set of common libraries used by multiple Atlassian products
projectCategory.name: Common Modules

fields.description:
h3. Summary

On the userlogin page, the os_destination GET parameter can be set by an attacker and sent as a link to a victim. When the victim logs in, they will be redirected to any site of the attacker's choice.
h3. Steps to reproduce:
 # Visit [https://BAMBOOINSTANCEDOMAIN/userlogin!doDefault.action?os_destination=HtTp://google.com|https://bambooinstancedomain/userlogin!doDefault.action?os_destination=HtTp://google.com]
 # Login (if not already logged in)

You should now be redirected to Google search.
h3. Notes

There seems to be some sort of filtering which happens on the os_destination parameter, but the odd capitalisation of HtTp bypasses this filter.

There was also some mention of JSESSIONID leakage in the original bug report, but we did not find any evidence of this while reproducing the bug.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Redirect validation allows urls with mixed letter case for protocol

fields.description:
SER-199 introduced changes that will NPE when the query string is null.  Since that is what happens when no query string is provided, it pretty much kills everything:

{noformat}
Sep 11, 2014 1:48:11 PM org.apache.catalina.core.StandardWrapperValve invoke
SEVERE: Servlet.service() for servlet [default] in context with path [/jira] threw exception
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at java.net.URLDecoder.decode(URLDecoder.java:136)
	at com.atlassian.seraph.filter.LoginFilter.decodeQueryString(LoginFilter.java:79)
	at com.atlassian.seraph.filter.LoginFilter.extractUserPasswordPair(LoginFilter.java:94)
	at com.atlassian.seraph.filter.PasswordBasedLoginFilter.login(PasswordBasedLoginFilter.java:58)
	at com.atlassian.seraph.filter.BaseLoginFilter.doFilter(BaseLoginFilter.java:110)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.filters.JiraLoginFilter.doFilter(JiraLoginFilter.java:70)
{noformat}
fields.summary: NPE when request.getQueryString() is null

fields.description:
I talked with [~mlassau] about what could be done to move to removing support for os_username and os_password in url parameters. We came up with the following plan:
1. change the existing code to by default not with url parameter values for os_username & os_password and release a new (minor version is okay) of seraph.
2. add a means to re-enable url parameter values for os_username & os_password such that applications can enable/disable support for it.

fields.description:
As can be seen from the attached screenshot, {{CachedPathMapper.cacheAllMap}} caches the security rules that apply for each individual URL that is queried and the value is nearly always (at least in JIRA's case) an empty collection with the default size of 10.  Further, the cache is not bounded by either space or time.

There must be a better way.
fields.summary: PathMapper cache is unnecessarily wasteful of memory

2014-05-29 00:23:22,092 ERROR [catalina-exec-48] [[Catalina].[localhost].[/].[action]] log Servlet.service() for servlet action threw exception

fields.description:
We currently use a custom class which extends the JiraSeraphAuthenticator, utilizing Apache's REMOTE_USER environment variable for authentication.  When accessing Jira's mobile version via /plugins/servlet/mobile the authentication process has glitches.

When I initially log in the Assigned to me list and all the issues assigned to me appear.

In the slide-out menu on the left I see the Assigned to Me, Reported by Me, and Recently Viewed filters.  The Favourites filter does not appear in the menu, and Not Logged in appears next to the avatar with a Log In link below it.

When I click the "Assigned to Me" filter I am taken to the Jira login screen at this URL: /plugins/servlet/mobile#login/filter/assigned. If I change the URL to: /plugins/servlet/mobile#filter/assigned the Assigned issue list appears correctly.  However, I am still not "Logged In". There is no Favourites in the menu, and Not Logged in still appears next to the avatar with a Log In link below it.

This is also the behaviour when clicking Assigned to Me, Reported by Me, or Recently Viewed.  I'm taken to the Jira login screen which I bypass by changing the URL, but I'm never truly logged in.

If I don't bypass the login screen by changing the URL and I log into the Jira login screen, the behaviour is the same as changing the URL.  I am still not "Logged In". There is no Favourites in the menu, and Not Logged in still appears next to the avatar with a Log In link below it.  Any subsequent clicks on the menu items results in another Jira login screen being presented.

It appears there something the mobile servlet is looking for that the JiraSeraphAuthenticator is not providing.
fields.summary: Custom Seraph Authenticator Partially Fails in Mobile Servlet

fields.description:
You should be able to *specify multiple* role-names by using comma separated values [accordingly this example in the documentation|http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-seraph/latest/services.html]:
{code}
<seraph-paths>
    <!-- You can configure any number of path elements -->
    <path name="admin">
        <url-pattern>/admin/*</url-pattern>
		<role-name>myapp-administrators, myapp-owners</role-name>
    </path>
</seraph-paths>
{code}

However, the user must be part of all roles specified in the configuration since the comma is like a "AND" logic operator.

This improvement to solely created for the option to change the comma logic to be something like an "OR" semantic instead, which means that an user who is part of the 'myapp-owners' role only like the example above will be correct.
fields.summary: Seraph configuration fails when I try to specify more than one group for role-name

fields.description:
See [https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-CONF-3476#c94769]

"This whole attribute kerfuffle is redundant with servlet 2.4 dispatchers, isn't it? The idea was to prevent re-application of the filter in a forward or error dispatch, but that's possible just by changing the web.xml configuration now. 

Should we fix it up in Seraph too? Remove all this crap from the filters and release a new major version which requires servlet 2.4?

Richard Atkins says:
That's right, it was only needed while there was no way to specify which dispatcher a filter should run in, which was added in servlet 2.4. We've been running with a 2.4 compliant container since we started shipping Tomcat 5.5.x with Confluence (any idea when?). 

We should cut servlet 2.4 versions of seraph, gzipfilter and sitemesh (we've already done a similar workaround for its double-filtering protection flag in the ProfilingPageFilter for 5.0, just so we could get the 404 page to be decorated consistently). Although really, we should rip and replace seraph with spring security before that happens"
fields.summary: Use 2.4 servlet spec and remove property designed to prevent double application of filters

fields.description:
To upgrade to Jira 5, I need to configure our custom authenticator by using Seraph via the already implemented SOAP web service. In the Seraph authenticator (named SeraphAuthenticate class), I also override the abstract method, getUser() and authenticate() extending from com.atlassian.seraph.auth.DefaultAuthenticator class in Seraph. 

Then I compile this as a Atlassian plugin using the command atlas-compile which in turn create a .jar file. I am not sure whether we are extending this DefaultAuthenticator correctly, you can request to have a look at the code if you want. I have then follow the instructions from http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-seraph/latest/configuration.html, which is configuring the seraph-config.xml and web.xml. I am not able to get any authentication while I try to login. 

For info, I have tried on SeraphAuthenticate by giving some parameter, username and password and it is able to authenticate via SOAP and return true or false value. But it seems everything is lost when I could not get any authentication by using this class. Can you provide me more information to configure authentication using Seraph other than override the DefaultAuthenticator class? I am in no where now, and would like you to enlighten me with some idea so that I can proceed with this authentication.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Not able to authenticate and configure Seraph with Jira 5

projectCategory.description: Set of common libraries used by multiple Atlassian products
projectCategory.name: Common Modules

fields.description:
Whenever anyone "authenticates" with Seraph they get a HttpSession.  This has a cost because Tomcat must keep a HttpSession object around for say 4 hours.  JAC was recently found to have 70MB of HttpSession objects in it (Bots where the main problem but still).

I propose that we change Seraph so that it no longer creates a session when it detects that the auth mechanism is BASIC AUTH

This would save on sessions for "Out Of Browser" REST calls such as curl et al..

So why is there a session really?
Seraph uses DefaultAuthenticator.LOGGED_IN_KEY in the session to know that a user has logged in on future requests.  This is really there for the browser experience.  Eg one login and then sessions of interaction.

Really old bits of JIRA code used to look for req.getSession().getAttribute(DefaultAuthenticator.LOGGED_IN_KEY) to get the current user instead of using the other Seraph AuthContext.getUser() mechanism.

These have been removed fro all intents and purposes in 4.4.4 I think.  (Its complicated but its never read only set...kinda...sorta...trust me)

If no session was created on BASIC AUTH calls then nothing in JIRA would break,  I also doubt whether any other apps are using LOGGED_IN_KEY to get the current user in code.

The purpose of this page is to find out of any other Seraph users reply on DefaultAuthenticator.LOGGED_IN_KEY being in a session DURING a BASIC AUTH call?

When to do this?
In the next major version of Seraph to get out in the version of the products choosing
fields.summary: Dont create sessions for BASIC AUTH requests

fields.description:
If you go to (eg) 
http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-seraph/latest/sso.html 

You will find a link to javadoc at http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-seraph/latest/apidocs/com/atlassian/seraph/auth/Authenticator.html
But this link goes nowhere.

It seems way back in the mists of time this used to link somewhere:
eg http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-seraph/1.1/sso.html 
links you to http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-seraph/1.1/apidocs/com/atlassian/seraph/auth/Authenticator.html
successfully.

I don't no whether javadoc generation was supposed to happen manually or automatically.
If we are unwilling/unable to fix the javadoc then we should at least remove the dead links from the documentation.
fields.summary: Javadoc generation not happening for Seraph

projectCategory.name: Common Modules

fields.description:
This change is required for the Crowd delegated authentication feature where the user details are only retrieved upon the first successful authentication.

The proposed change is to authenticate the user first before retrieving the user details in the {{login(..)}} method. Only retrieve the user details after the authentication is successful.  The implication is that classes overriding {{authenticate(..)}} *must* handle the case where the user is not found, and return {{false}}.
fields.summary: Change login behaviour to authenticate without finding user first

projectCategory.description: Set of common libraries used by multiple Atlassian products
projectCategory.name: Common Modules

fields.description:
The new Crowd embedded work means that the User object is now immutable.  Best practice as they say.

However this has exposed a problem in Seraph thats been there for years but was saved by the fact that the old OSUser was mutable.

Seraph (via the default authenticator) sticks a User object in the session and uses that to indicate loggedinedness.  (Is that even a word :)

The SecurityFilter use this exact object to set the AuthenticationContext threadlocal and also much of JIRA code does nasty things like this

User remoteUser = (User) httpSession.getAttribute(DefaultAuthenticator.LOGGED_IN_KEY);

However if we change the users attributes say the email address or fullname, then this will never be reflected in the app until the user logs out.

We could in our user update code tweak the session and authcontext however imagine the case where an admin changes the user full name.  We cant get that users session to tweak.

In JIRAs case part of the app will show the updated name (the issue navigator reads from the user manager) and parts wont (that use the auth context and or session). 

Mark L made the point that code should not assume that the session key is any other than a Principal but I think that horse has bolted, probably in and around 2004.

Does Confluence suffer from this problem on user update??  What about Bamboo??

I propose we tweak the code with a method to "normalise" the Principal object it passes back.
fields.summary: The Seraph Principal in session relies on mutaable OSUser objects.  The new Crowd embedded work has revealed this bug

With LDAP connectivity in JIRA, we would like to be able to indicate whether a login error is caused by a remote communication error
(as opposed to unknown error).

fields.description:
BaseLoginFilter.login() says that we should return a status code of LOGIN_ERROR ("error") if an error stops us from completing the authentication of username/password.

This then is stored in a Request attribute that the host application can use to let the user trying to log in that an error is stopping authentication at this stage.
fields.summary: PasswordBasedLoginFilter.login() is not returning LOGIN_ERROR correctly

projectCategory.description: Set of common libraries used by multiple Atlassian products
projectCategory.name: Common Modules

fields.description:
The new session fixation code we put into Seraph during 2.3.1 has broken JIRA 4.2 when basic auth is used.

In order to be more secure, when a new session is established, Seraph will tear down the old session, copy a few thing across and create a new session.

For non "basic auth" login this works because you only "establish" the session when you present os_username/os_password in the request that is when you fill in the login form.

However for "basic auth" requests, the username and password is presented with EVERY request and hence Seraph will tear down the session and recreate it ON every request.

We have code in JIRA that tracks "valueUnbound" events from sessions and removes internal state on objects. The Temporary Attachment code is an example.

In this case the session tear down cause the temporary attachment manager to "clean itself" up even though the manager object lives on into the next session.

We need to fix Seraph to do something different on basic auth requests and hence not caused the session disruption and other flow on effects from that.

http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-23188
fields.summary: Session fixation prevention has broken things when basic auth is used in Seraph

fields.description:
The {{BaseLoginFilter}} abstract class is meant to be extended, but some things have default visibility, which means they can only be extended from within the same package.

We should make it possible to extend this class from other packages.
fields.summary: Modify BaseLoginFilter to make it suitable for extension

projectCategory.name: Common Modules

fields.description: Previously customers could bypass authentication by providing os_authType=guest.  Since 2.3.x this no longer works which means clients have to change their customisations to pass in 'none'.  We should change the AuthType enum to simply return none instead of throwing an IllegalArgumentException if there's no match for the enum.
fields.summary: Custom authtype should return NONE instead of erroring out

projectCategory.description: Set of common libraries used by multiple Atlassian products
projectCategory.name: Common Modules

fields.description:
The constructer for SecurityConfigImpl calls configureAuthenticator() which calls authenticator.init() and passes in a reference to itself. Unfortunately this happens before SecurityConfigImpl is fully initialised. This means, for example, if the init() method in a custom authenticator calls config.getLogoutURL() it will be returned null as the loginUrlStrategy in SecurityConfigImpl has not be initialsed yet. 

We should probably fix this so that authenticator.init() is called at the very end of the constructor.
fields.summary: SecurityConfigImpl constructor calls authenticator.init() too soon

fields.description:
This change [http://svn.atlassian.com/fisheye/changelog/public?cs=39411] -[http://svn.atlassian.com/fisheye/cru/CR-517#c3145]- has broken confluence's invite plugin. 

The plugin used to rely on the fact that after calling {{getAuthenticator().login(ServletActionContext.getRequest(),                ServletActionContext.getResponse(), username, password, true);}} the request.getRemoteUser will return the username of logged in user. After we changed the BaseLoginFilter to cache the principle it no longer does that.

I changed the plugin so it is no longer affected...
fields.summary: request.getRemoteUser() does not return a logged in user

fields.description:
Seraph decodes all base64 strings without specifying which charset to use when decoding them, leading to it just using whatever the default platform file encoding is set to. This is preventing any code that relies on Seraph for basic authentication from authenticating users that have accents on any characters in their usernames or passwords (e.g. Confluence WebDAV), where that code is running on Mac OS or Linux.

Surprisingly, the client applications are not sending encoded UTF-8 authorization headers, but ISO-Latin-1. This should change to always use ISO-Latin-1 for HTTP Basic Authentication (Authorization) headers, since that is what browsers actually use to encode their usernames and passwords.
fields.summary: Seraph is using the wrong encoding when decoding basic authentication headers

projectCategory.description: Set of common libraries used by multiple Atlassian products
projectCategory.name: Common Modules

fields.description:
The canonical version is at https://extranet.atlassian.com/display/DEV/Rest+Authentication+Specification+Proposal and you should really read that in case this changes. But at the moment it reads:

{quote}
If the 'os_authType' parameter is specified, its value will determine which type will be required for this request. Possible values are:

    * basic
    * cookie
    * any

If its value is 'basic', valid HTTP BASIC credentials will be required in the HTTP header. If none present, the application must return an HTTP response with the status code of 401 - authentication required. If the credentials are present but invalid, the application must return an HTTP response with the status code of 401 containing a Status and a subcode of 401.

If its value is 'cookie', a valid session cookie will be required in the HTTP header. If none is present, the application must return an HTTP response with the status code of 401 with an HTTP header on the response:

WWW-Authenticate: cookie

If the cookie are present but invalid, the application must return an HTTP response with the status code of 401 containing a Status and a subcode of 401.

If its value is 'any', either a session cookie or BASIC authentication credentials may be present. If none present, the application allows the request to continue as an anonymous request. However, if the cookie are present but invalid or if the HTTP BASIC credentials are present but invalid, the application must return an HTTP response with the status code of 401 containing a Status and a subcode of 401.

All requests with URI's beginning with "/rest/" must be treated as if the 'os_authType' query parameter was set to 'any'.

Without os_authType set, if invalid HTTP BASIC credentials or an invalid cookie is present but invalid, the request will continue without the user logged in.
{quote}
fields.summary: seraph needs to support the "REST authentication spec"

fields.description:
The current remember me cookie is not a secure as it could be.  We would like to replace this with a better, token based mechanism.

This is described really well here by Charles

http://fishbowl.pastiche.org/2004/01/19/persistent_login_cookie_best_practice/

It wont quite be exactly as outlined here but it is close.
fields.summary: Add a more secure remember me service implementation to Seraph
